key_insight: Skyra is a multimodal large language model that detects human-perceivable visual artifacts in AI-generated videos and produces grounded, human-readable evidence instead of only a binary real/fake label.
problem_solved: Existing AI-generated video detectors focus on binary classification and lack explainability, making them hard for humans to trust or act on. Skyra fills this gap by localizing artifacts in space and time and providing interpretable artifact-level reasoning as evidence.
method: Specialized MLLM ingests video frames (and optionally audio/metadata) to reason across visual and temporal cues.
Automatic artifact identification: model outputs artifact types/locations (e.g., inconsistent lighting, warped geometry, temporal jitter) with spatio-temporal grounding.
Generates natural-language explanations and visual overlays (heatmaps/bboxes/timestamped cues) as human-interpretable evidence for each detection.
impact: Skyra improves trust and utility of AI-generated video detection by turning opaque binary decisions into actionable, explainable evidence for forensic analysts and practitioners. This enables better human–AI collaboration for moderation, audit, and legal workflows.
visual_elements: End-to-end pipeline diagram: video input → frame sampling → MLLM artifact reasoning → explanation + overlays
Before/after frame examples with artifact overlays (heatmaps, bounding boxes) and short textual explanations
Spatio-temporal timeline visualization showing when and where artifacts appear across a clip
Bar or radar chart comparing binary-only detectors vs. Skyra on explainability metrics (evidence clarity, localization accuracy, user trust)
paper_title: Skyra: AI-Generated Video Detection via Grounded Artifact Reasoning
paper_authors: Yifei Li, Wenzhao Zheng, Yanran Zhang, Runze Sun, Yu Zheng
